Topic.Title: "FB haz more value than amzn", and stok X iz worth more than stok Y.... Bla bla bla

Message.Msg: Say if you own a share of AMZN stock at $250 and AMZN goes bankrupt today. Which part of the company will you be getting back? An office chair? How about a paper clip? None of the above. Also, will you ever be able to cast votes DIRECTLY to any of the AMZN ballots? No you can only qualify to cast a proxy vote. If you want to split hair on "share" and "ownership", you can, but I won't be entertaining. In my point of view, your existence as a share holder is to provide financial leverage to the company. No more, no less. You are lucky if the board of directors vote 'YES' to give you dividends as a token of thanks to their successes or failures.

Topic.Title: Sybs just did a read of many charts and findz the following short in mid term prediction:

Message.Msg: "Secular bear market." Oh boy, I like that phrase. You should be a stock broker.-promoter. Let's see now...first, who invented this catchy phrase "secular bear market?" And who invented the definition of a "secular bear market?" And what makes it "secular" as opposed to say "non-secular?" And once you get through explaining that one, how about this one: What defines a "bear" "market?" Is it defined as the DOW trading at near all time highs? If so, then I guess we are in that "bear market" of yours. Truth is, it's all word games, invented lingo by those making a career out of selling stocks or brokering sales of stocks to the public. No such thing. Just arbitrary pumping and/or dumping, all day, every day, where no one but the pumpers/dumpers themsleves know what they plan to do next. So, today's so-called "bear" can turn turn into tomorrow's "bull" or vice versa, thus rendering any attempt to label the game as being a "Bull" or "Bear" useless. Once again, you are attempting to portray yourself as one who knows the mindset of what the big money people who control the bid-ask are planning to do in the future, based upon what they did in the past (i.e. you think that by looking at a chart, or "RSI" or whatever past-tense concept you choose, that you can sort of predict what is going to happen henceforth. But elsewhere you claim that you are not a "short term" (however you define short term...) trader. Comment: Please make up your mind. Either you are a short term trader or not.

Topic.Title: Sybs just did a read of many charts and findz the following short in mid term prediction:

Message.Msg: Is the name of the game here that you make a profit or that you portray yourself as some kind of guru of stock trading or both? I think you should ask yourself that question, because if it's about you trying to prove yourself as a guru, then you should ask yourself why it is important to you that you should care one wit about impressing a bunch of total strangers on a message board. These are folks who you will probably never meet in person, and, thus, even from the silly angle that "showing off my prowess makes me feel good," you will never get the opportunity in the real world. In any case, if you are not a day trader (however one defines that concept), then what gives with all of your "the chart says," and "RSI," and "support level" talk? That is the talk of someone who WANTS some short term movement to go his way. Otherwise, why mention it at all? What's your point in bringing it up?

Message.Title: Actuallly, shorting is kind of a legalized fraud
Message.Msg: When someone shorts, his'her thoughts are that the stock is overvalued. So, you borrow shares and sell them. In other words, you are selling something that you believe is overvalued in order to try to profit from it later. So, in your mind at least, you are selling something that you believe to be overvalued to someone else. That's a kind of fraudulent activity, though legal.

Topic.Title: Actuallly, shorting is kind of a legalized fraud

Message.Msg: When someone LONGS, his'her thoughts are that the stock is undervalued. So, you buy shares and hold them. In other words, you are buying something that you believe is undervalued in order to try to profit from it later. Message.Title: Pre-diction, for what it's worth...
Message.Msg: As I stated in an earlier post, it's impossible to predict what will happen at any given point in time unless you claim to have prophetic power and are thus capable of reading the minds of the folks who control the ongoing bid-ask markets. Thus, throw out all the charts, RSI, support, volume, baloney analysis. However, from a purely psychological standpoint, I believe that as long as you see a lot of negative posts from the public in forums like stock message boards and YahooFunance comments, about stocks and the economic situation in general, the overrall market will probably continue to set new multi-year highs (with some pull backs mixed in, of course).

Topic.Title: Actuallly, shorting is kind of a legalized fraud

Message.Msg: You wrote: "So, in your mind at least you are buying something you believe to be undervalued to someone else. That's a kind of fraudulent activity, though legal." Well, not necessarily. Perhaps when you bought it your thinking was that it is undervalued. And you hope to sell it to someone else who likewise thinks it is undervalued even at the new, higher price. Or even if the new buyer believes he is paying fair value. Short selling, however, means that the shorter believes it is OVERVALUED. The fact that the buyer of such shorted shares believes otherwise is no the point. The point is that from the SHORT SELLERS PERSPECTIVE, he believes that he is legally defrauding the buyer by selling him what he believes to be overvalued shares..

Topic.Title: Actuallly, shorting is kind of a legalized fraud

Message.Msg: Btw, people buy and then later sell a stock because their thought process is that they need the money right now for whatever reason, not necessarily because they now think it is overvalued. Short sellers, on the other hand, do not have that way of thinking. Their thinking is not that they need to short because they need the money. Rather, they are shorting because they believe the stock is ovevalued, PERIOD. And I'm not saying it's outright fraud to short sell. Because it is legal. But, just saying...

Topic.Title: PIN tomorrow now looks like $250,,10KPUTS and 8K CALLS--Tanky Tanky

Message.Msg: Obviously, you will know what the report says before the open. The target is only 150k. Don't be surprised if it beats. This stuff is often lumpy and last month was terrible. If it comes in on target or above at the market keeps going up. LNKD getting beat up after hours. That's what happens when a stock is priced for perfection. AMZN has done well over time, not taking poundings probably as bad as they should have. My overall question with the markets is do they just keep going up regardless of below target revenues? Seems to me we are just adding lots of air and then hoping that miraculously everything just works out in the end. I'm net long but a PUT buyer and or short in what I consider high priced stocks that are not fundamentally doing very well. AMZN is a great example.

Topic.Title: Mini-Crash Possible Frid through Mond?

Message.Msg: That's a dream ex goldbug. Like I said in my last post 150k is not a big number. I think anything above 100k to just short of 150k the market barely farts. If it's above and 180k + to over 200k the market probably is up a ton. Of course the actual jobs added will probably suck wage wise but they'll be throwing a party on TV. gee will be posting every other post here and we will be sure to see the ground hog crew. :-) These numbers are usually lumpy so last month may have been an anomaly. Topic.Title: PIN tomorrow now looks like $250,,10KPUTS and 8K CALLS--Tanky Tanky

Message.Msg: What a paradox, today we have lowest employment in 5 years due to the, often revised, counting methods . Tomorrow we'll very likely have bad job numbers because is the "actual" hiring figures hence the "real" indicator of the underlying economy a la the Tale of Two Cities . The key in shorting high flyers or momo stocks is price action weakness not fundamentals. Right now I'm seeing more and more weakness in bubble stocks like NFLX, LNKD, and AMZN. Does it means that they collapse? No. But I do expect them to have some nice little pullbacks when the market retreat. If they failed to advance when the market shoot up again than it will be obvious that the show is over.
